title: add opt-in githook to config
body:
**What**: Add `ghooks` and `opt-cli` to allow regular contributors to automatically run a `validate` script before committing.

**Why**: To help automate the process of regularly contributing code. However, because it's `opt-in` new contributors wont have a barrier to contributing.

**How**:
- Add `validate` script to run: `npm run build & npm run style & npm run test`
- Add `opt-cli` and `ghooks` as dependencies. `ghooks` auto-installs githooks when installed (backs up any previously installed githooks). These preinstalled githooks will run any hooks configured in the `package.json`. `opt-cli` will check for the existence of an `.opt-in`/`.opt-out` file and check the contents to determine whether the given command should be run. In this case, for the `pre-commit` githook to run the new `validate` script, you must have a `.opt-in` file with `pre-commit` in the contents.
- Add `.opt-in` and `.opt-out` to the `gitignore` so people can have their own preferences for whether githooks should be run (in this case only `opt --in` is implemented, so we really only need a `.opt-in` file, but I figured we could just add both and not worry about it in the future).

Happy to answer any questions about this! I feel that the real value add here is for regular contributors to automatically run this new `validate` script before committing to avoid the: "whoops, looks like I need to fix that and amend my commit"

We could also use `pre-push` if you want it run less.

Thoughts :thought_balloon:?

Introduce typings for npm package
body:
TypeScript 1.6 has introduced new way of resolving module names that mimics the Node.js module resolution algorithm. This means the TypeScript compiler can currently load typings that are bundled with npm packages. 
Please include `lodash.d.ts` file into npm package and reference it from `package.json` file

```
{
...
    "typings": "./lodash.d.ts"
}
```

title: Document old names for functions inside the documentation
body: As someone who has used lodash for a while, it's very confusing when I remember a function name and I look through the docs and it's missing, only to find it on the changelog. It would be very useful it we could have a line next to each function like "previously known as pluck [link to changelog]"

title: Split `̀fp/divide` into two methods
body:
I saw the `divide` method appear in https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/6eb0cb156505adfb5356fd67255c131055c637c8.
For `divide`, do you think it might be interesting, or is it too confusing, to have two functions in `fp`?
- `_.divideBy(10)(2) // => 5` (arg order reversed compared to current), for when you know the dividend, and the data is the divisor (I have 10 pies, but I don't know how many people will attend the birthday party).
- `_.divide(10)(2) // => 0.2` (current arg order in both vanilla and fp), for when you know the divisor, and the data is the dividend (10 people will attend the birthday party, but I don't know how many pies I will be able to make).

My aim by proposing this is to help avoid the use of `partial` (or custom functions) in a flow construct. It's easy enough to call divide with args in one order or the other if you have all the data and/or variables, but in a flow construct, depending on whether you want the known value be divided or for it to divide the data, you may have to use partial or a new function calling divide.

title: Deep clone map with nested maps.
body:
Hello,

I'm stuck with issue of deep cloning map which contains other maps. It seems that values of nested map are not cloned. Please look at the next code:

``` js
let m1 = new Map([
  [1, {a: '1'}],
  [2, {b: '2'}]
])

let m2 = new Map([
  [3, {c: '3'}],
  [4, {d: '4'}]
])

let m3 = new Map([
  ['m1', m1],
  ['m2', m2]
])

let m4 = _.cloneDeep(m3);

console.log(m4===m3); // log false - Ok
console.log(m4.get('m1')===m3.get('m1')); // log true - but should be false also`
```

Is this bug or am I doing something wrong?

Tested with lodash 4.6.1 [http://jsbin.com/jubiwaquma/1/edit?html,js,output](http://jsbin.com/jubiwaquma/1/edit?html,js,output)

title: Follow up to #2132.
body:
Sorry for putting this here, but you locked comments on #2132. I need to get this out, and I see no other way. Go ahead and delete this when you've read it.

I really did not expect this reaction. But I'm usually oblivious to this kind of thing. So I genuinely apologize if I offended you (or anyone). It was just meant as a joke, if a stupid one. I hardly gave it a second thought, but I guess I should have.

To be clear: I greatly support open source and creative commons, so I gladly waive copyright. (Even though I did not submit any code samples, so for this particular pull request, the issue was moot.)

I'd be happy if you could just go ahead with the pull request and pretend I didn't make any stupid jokes.

title: _.find in 4.6.1
body: In version 3.10.1 we have method `_.find`, is method available in version 4.6.1?

title: Re-ordered arguments for fp.isEqualWith + some additional tests for lodash.isEqualWith
body:
Here's the fix. It seems to work OK.

I wasn't sure how many tests you'd expect for an FP version of an existing operation (there aren't any tests for `fp.isMatchWith`), so I converted some of the basic ones from `test.js`.

Also, I was surprised that the original `lodash.isEqualWith` is tested for expected positive results, but not for expected negative results, so I added some additional tests there, too.

title: Better FP argument order for `isEqualWith`
body: Hi. It seems to me there is (at least) one lodash operation left that would benefit from a custom argument order for the FP version: `isEqualWith`. The argument order should probably be `(c, a, b)`. I'm guessing it was missed by accident, since you did fix `isMatchWith`.

title: sortedUnion
body:
Having `sortedUniq` it would be also nice to have `sortedUnion` that would benefit from the knowledge that all collections are sorted.
`sortedUnion` should work just like `union`, but expecting all arrays to be sorted.
It's not clear though whether the result should be sorted or be in order of first element appearance (like in `union`).

title: Question about `find` shorthand - lodash 3.10.1 vs 4.6.1
body:
I've noticed a discrepancy (which made a sneaky bug appear) when moving code between a project using Lodash 3 and another using Lodash 4.

I've [made a fiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/ashclarke/fyda60ru/) to illustrate. The gist is that they return different results for a property called index, when using the `matchesProperty` shorthand. There is probably an obvious reason why that I have missed.

Aware that a lot of changes have occurred between the two. Wondered if you had any insight to provide on the why :)

title: Memoizing functions with multiple arguments
body:
The docs mention that, "By default, the first argument provided to the memoized function is used as the map cache key"

It would be great if the cache were multi-dimensional so `_.memoize` worked well out of the box with longer functions. i.e. functions with more arguments.

If there is a simple way to do this already, we can close. If this sounds useful I can look into submitting a PR

Migrating from underscore.js: context-parameter is missing
body:
Hey there,

I tried to migrate from underscore 1.8.3 to lodash with your [wiki-entry](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Migrating).
Problem is, that my app + plugins use the `context`-parameter all over, f.e. in [`_.each`](http://underscorejs.org/#each). As far as I know, [lodash `_.each`](https://lodash.com/docs#forEach) does not support this.

Is there a workaround to this?

title: Lodash development workflow
body:
Im trying to understand what lodash development workflow is, and how exactly code from master branch goes to `npm` branch?

In `master` I see many commits in one big `/lodash.js` file. Just one single JS file. And all pull-request are made to `master`.

But there is an `npm` branch for npm publishing, where all code splitted to many files. Where the source of lodash? Is it the `npm` branch, and there is some non-published build logic? Or source is `master` branch, and all changes goes to `npm` (and also to `npm-packages`) branch by copy&paste from `master` single file?

D

title: _.kebabCase removed some accent but not others
body:
Seem like `deburr` doesn't support a lot of UTF-8 characters. Isn't it better to just simple `kebapCase()` without `deburr` and let the programer decide how they gonna trim out the accent?

Sample case:

```
_.kebabCase("tôi tên là đức tạ")
"toi-ten-la-đức-tạ"
```

title: sortBy comparator is called on arrays with a single item
body:
Can be reproduced with the following:

``` javascript
_.sortBy([1], (a, b) => { console.log('I WAS CALLED'); return a; })
//=> I WAS CALLED
[1]
```

This is particularly problematic if you are comparing values returned from a function.

``` javascript
_.sortBy([{ ... }], (a, b) => a.getLeft() > b.getRight())
// BOOM
```

title: Typescript - Reference to "this" lost in 2nd level fat arrow functions
isPlainObject false positive with unusual prototypes
body:
Cf. https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2968

When the prototype of an object has no `constructor` property of its own (e.g., `Object.create({ foo: "bar" })`), `_.isPlainObject` can find an inherited Object constructor and falsely conclude that the object is plain. This can be remedied by verifying that `constructor` is an own property of the object's prototype: http://jsbin.com/hezeqilega/edit?js,output

P.S. What is the purpose of the `Ctor instanceof Ctor` [check](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/cf74ebeb71028590e12d49d14a888bbef3c3169f/lodash.js#L10546)? The following Function#toString verification seems strictly stronger... is there a performance advantage to the former?

title: iterable.length has been deprecated
body:
Getting a very large and obtrusive warning printed to the development console in Chrome that appears to be coming from _.forEach. Sure, it's just a warning, but it's really getting in the way of seeing my debug output. I'm running a node.js application with React, Redux, RxJs, Babel, Webpack, and probably others I'm missing. This would hopefully be an easy fix regardless of other libraries though.

```
iterable.length has been deprecated, use iterable.size or iterable.count(). This warning will become a silent error in a future version. Error
    at List.Object.defineProperty.get (http://localhost:3000/my-react-app.js:61829:22)
    at http://localhost:3000/my-react-app.js:28876:33
    at Function.forEach (http://localhost:3000/my-react-app.js:32590:12)
    at MyReactComponent.render (http://localhost:3000/my-react-app.js:125307:16)
    at ReactCompositeComponentMixin._renderValidatedComponentWithoutOwnerOrContext (http://localhost:3000/my-react-app.js:8292:35)
    at ReactCompositeComponentMixin._renderValidatedComponent (http://localhost:3000/my-react-app.js:8312:33)
    at wrapper [as _renderValidatedComponent] (http://localhost:3000/my-react-app.js:2043:22)
    at ReactCompositeComponentMixin._updateRenderedComponent (http://localhost:3000/my-react-app.js:8265:37)
    at ReactCompositeComponentMixin._performComponentUpdate (http://localhost:3000/my-react-app.js:8249:11)
    at ReactCompositeComponentMixin.updateComponent (http://localhost:3000/my-react-app.js:8178:13)
```

If I click on the forEach line, it takes me in the source to this line in the forEach function:
`baseEach(collection, baseCastFunction(iteratee));`

Using the changelog, I added `@since` to the methods JSDoc.

I did not really proofread this, because I'm now :sleeping::zzz: (If you don't mind, I don't really plan to anyway...) I think that if these versions are really important, they will be fixed over time, but I don't think so.

Please do not merge this, before I at least fix two things:
- There are a lot of methods, for which I did not find a version in the changelog, so I'm guessing they are they were included in Underscore to start with (that or I missed it). I added `@since ?` for now. What would you link the message to be?
- Some methods were renamed, so I wrote `@since x.x.x (RENAMED in y.y.y)` (where x.x.x is sometimes `?`). What would you prefer that I show? x.x.x, y.y.y or a combination of both?

This should be easy to find & replace, just need to know what to write. Off to bed now, have a good one!

title: Memoize property paths given to stringToPath
body:
In many applications `stringToPath` will be indirectly called with the same path multiple times. These paths may be complex and relatively expensive to convert to an array path.

It probably is worth considering memoizing the results of `stringToPath` for an easy perf which I suspect will outweigh any of the memory considerations.

title: _.flip does not work correctly with lodash/fp
Webpack + lodash AMD + IE runtime error
body:
Hi lodash maintainers,

We have encountered a runtime issue in IE when bundling lodash methods via AMD with a vanilla webpack config and lodash 4.5.1. It seems to choke on the `toString` method file, specifically at [line 11](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/amd/toString.js#L11). 

Changing the `Symbol` expression to `symbolProto` resolves this problem. I guess the `Symbol` polyfill in IE is missing a `prototype` method?

I have attached a zip file containing a simple test case with the webpack config used to generate the bundle. I also note that the test case executes fine in Chrome (I don't have access to Edge, Safari or Firefox to test it at this moment).

Thanks for such a great library and hope this can be addressed easily.

[amdtest.zip](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/files/152812/amdtest.zip)

title: Add _.toBoolean()
_.merge behaves differently for first and second level properties
body:
Case one. _First_ level. Object + Array.

```
$ n_
n_ > _.merge({bar: 'bam'}, ['a','b','c']);
{ '0': 'a',
  '1': 'b',
  '2': 'c',
  bar: 'bam' }
```

Produces object.

Case two. _Second_ level. Object + Array.

```
n_ > _.merge({foo: {bar: 'bam'}}, {foo: ['a','b','c']});
{ foo: [ 'a', 'b', 'c' ] }
```

Produces array. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

That is very unexpected. Although, the same happens in lodash v3.

Bug?
If not then how to make the two cases consistent?

title: Feature request: support the Closure Compiler in advanced mode
body:
Could lodash support the Closure Compiler in advanced mode? (Or if it already does, that should be documented.)

As far as I can tell, the Closure Compiler in advanced mode is the only minifier that does non-trivial property renaming, and is widely agreed to be best minifier if one can follow the restrictions it imposes.

According to #1051, "it requires lots of property escaping and corrections for overly aggressive minifications".  Is that still the case?  If it is, are you open to contributions in this direction?

title: chore(package): update coveralls to version 2.11.8
body: http://greenkeeper.io/

title: Remove custom rearg for `update`
body:
Remove custom rearg for `update` to have the same arg order as `set`
As discussed in #1832:

> How I see it:
> the value argument in `update` is like the func argument in `set` (you could replicate set with update by passing `_.constant(someValue)` as func), so it'd make sense having them at the same position. So that, for example, if you need to modify your code to use `update` rather than `set`, you do not have to change the order of the arguments.
> I also think it is more readable to have as first argument what you want to change, rather than how to change it.

title: Add failing test for mergeWith with multi-ref source object
body:
This seems pretty straightfoward to me. I've got a source object
I want to merge which has two keys, only one of which exists in
the object I want to merge into. Both keys in the source object
point to the same object, an array.

What I expect to come out of the merge is an object where the
key that existed before has been modified to contain the values
of the array too, and the key that didn't exist just got added
with the values of the array _only_.

What actually happens is the two keys in the final object are
exactly the same, a strict equals comparison is true. This is
unexpected.

We can take this problem a little further and start with an initial
object with both keys from the source object defined and set to
different things:

``` js
var food = {
  vegetables: ['carrot'],
  greens: ['cabbage']
};
```

The result of `mergeWith` will actually end up destroying data because
`actual.greens` will no longer contain the element `cabbage`. This initial
state also produces an ordering problem. If you swap the order of the
keys in the source object, the final result is different - you end up with
`actual.vegetables` equal to `['cabbage', 'brocolli', 'peas']` and have
lost the `carrot` element. Merges with the same keys and data in the
source object feels to me like something that should be deterministic.

The problem appears to stem from `baseMergeDeep`'s stack because
the customiser function is only executed once, for the first key.
It feels like a bad assumption to make is that if you've seen a
source key's value once, the merge result will be the same no
matter what initial key you're merging into.

title: sumBy returns bool instead of integer when the result equals 1
body: I've noticed that sumBy in Lodash 4 returns bool true instead of 1 if the sum is 1. If the sum is 2 or more it returns an integer as usual. Is this expected behavior?

title: pad{left,right} 4.5.1-npm-packages release (and other releases as well?)
body:
Hey all!

I noticed that `_.padleft` and `_.padright` packages only contained `LICENSE` files within them for the `4.5.1-npm-packages` release.
- https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tree/4.5.1-npm-packages/lodash.padleft
- https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tree/4.5.1-npm-packages/lodash.padright

Also noticed they're not in the docs anymore, so I'm assuming they've been dropped from the API. Was wondering if keeping these packages is a bug or if they exist for backwards compatibility?

Thanks! Also sorry if this isn't the most appropriate place for this question; let me know if there's a google group or something better.

title: #2054 improve debounce testability
body: Replaced all calls to local copy of Date.now to use the original function.

title: Question: _chain()....map and this
body:
I am having some trouble figuring out how to do something I had working fine in an older version of lodash.

Here is the old code:

``` js
return _.chain(this.instructorIds)
  .unique()
  .map((id)=> this._accountService.get(id))
  .value()
```

In the latest version I try this:

``` js
return _.chain(this.instructorIds)
  .uniq()
  .map((id)=> this._accountService.get(id))
  .value()
```

But it fails at the this._accountService.get saying that accountService is undefined.  It seems "this" is being lost but I'm not really sure how to bind my the correct this into the chain.  I used the arrow function initially to avoid this kind of problem.

If you have a moment would you please provide some guidance?

Thanks

title: Problem testing debounce with sinon
Update array element at index
fp/mergeWith from 4.3 to 4.5 exponentially slower, more memory usage
body:
We have data in the form:

```
[
  { '1': [ DOMNode ], '25': [ DOMNode, DOMNode ] },
  { '1': [ DOMNode ] },
  ...
]
```

Where DOMNodes are xmldom elements. Previously, we used `reduce(mergeWith(concat))`. However, upon upgrading to to lodash 4.5, things that were previously taking less than a millisecond are taking now over a minute by the third pass of this function. Waiting longer causes Node to run out of memory. I suspect this is because of a deep clone, when it isn't needed.

title: How to convert a custom function to an fp function?
_.lowercase is replacing some characters for space
body:
_.lowercase('example@mail.com') gives as a result example mail com
This is different from the String.toLowerCase() behaviour.

title: uniqBy throw an error when target property is undefined
body:
It is near impossible to track down the issue when accidentally referring to non-existent property, e.g.

``` js
cinemas = _.uniqBy(cinemas, 'id');
```

This was in the code. However, there is no property `cinemas[].id`. There is `cinemas[].result.id`.
As it is, the function behaves without any warning returning a single result.
